item.title: Is it possible to deport and prohibit unemployed EU citizens from returning?
item.description:
Steve Peers Germany’s recent exploration of expelling unemployed EU citizens has sparked interest among critics of EU free movement in the UK. As this topic gains traction, it’s timely to clarify the circumstances under which EU citizens can be expelled. While the EU Citizens’ Directive empowers Member States to expel citizens for reasons related to public policy, security, or health, it explicitly prohibits using these grounds for economic reasons. Consequently, the rules for expelling unemployed EU citizens lie elsewhere within the Directive...

item.title: A Time for Entrepreneurs
item.description:
The concept of job security has become almost contradictory in recent times. It’s rare to find guaranteed employment, and even the usual promises of job stability for good performance are fading. We’ve faced recessions before, but this one is so significant that it might earn a name like “The Great Recession,” reminiscent of the depression our parents and grandparents endured. Facing a severe economic downturn is never positive. Job losses without readily available replacements are becoming a harsh reality for many...

item.title: The Court of Justice of the European Union clarifies the access of EU citizens to benefits after leaving employment.
item.description:
Steve Peers The recent Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) decision in the Alimanovic case provides further clarification on EU citizens’ access to benefits in other Member States, a complex issue. Similar to last year’s Dano ruling, it takes a stricter stance than previous interpretations of EU law. However, like its predecessor, this judgment leaves some questions unanswered. This analysis will delve into the judgment itself, its implications for EU citizens’ access to benefits, and the UK government’s plans to renegotiate its EU membership...

item.title: Tech Jobs Come Calling
item.description:
Although the Great Recession continues, the impact varies across industries. In fact, the technology sector is performing quite well in terms of employment. From November to December of last year, while 85,000 jobs were lost overall, the tech industry actually added 5,200 new positions. This suggests that technology might be a promising field. However, having technological skills doesn’t guarantee employment. Many factory workers, for instance, would likely agree. The manufacturing sector was already moving overseas even before the recession...
